subject: Design
subcategory: Design Disasters and What They Teach Us
title: The Juicero: Over-Engineering a Juice Squeeze
description: A quick win: understand The Juicero: Over-Engineering a Juice Squeeze.

hook.text: A $700 WiFi-connected juicer that squeezed proprietary bags ‚Äî you could squeeze them by hand just as well.

buildup.text: The device used 4 tons of force to squeeze proprietary fruit packs. It had custom chips, a motor, and a QR scanner.

discovery.text: Bloomberg reporters squeezed the packs by hand and got juice just as fast. The machine was unnecessary.

twist.text: The company shut down within five months of the Bloomberg article. $120 million in venture capital, gone.

climax.text: Juicero became a symbol of Silicon Valley excess ‚Äî over-engineering problems that don't need solving.

punchline.text: The most expensive lesson in design: solve real problems, not imaginary ones.

quiz.question: Why did Juicero fail?
options: Hand-squeezing the packs worked just as well, making the $400 machine unnecessary
